title: Single storey "g" for German 'locl' substitute?
content:
I'm making a big multilingual sans serif and by default, the "a" and the "g" are double storey. I do include the single story versions available by "salt" because this feature works virtually everywhere, where there is Opentype).

However, I've heard that the Germans mostly use the single story _g_. I've searched pictures of various street signs in Germany and Austria and I haven't found any double story g's.

Would it be ok to include 'locl' feature for German language to substitute only the g (while leaving the "a" double story)? I do understand that the single story g has its roots in Fraktur. And is it a German-only preference or the neighbour languages like Dutch, Danish, Swedish, etc. look more natural with a single storey g?

In the attachment, there's an example with single and double storey g's. To my eyes, the combination of single story g and double story a looks more "natural" in a German text. Don't look at the kerning, I didn't start polishing it yet.

author: goloub

comments.content:
I am living in Austria and have never heard that germans mostly use the single storey g. For example, Erik Spiekermann himself designed his famous [FF Meta](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414004031/http:/www.identifont.com/show?3MV) with a double storey g.

See also the following pic of german street signs:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414004031im_/http:/typophile.com/files/strassenschilder-bsp-juedisches-museum_5736.jpg)

Two English types from the 1920s: Gill Sans (two-storey) and Monotype Grotesque (one-storey).  
Two German types from the 1920s: Kabel (two-storey) and Futura (one-storey).  
I would say it’s up to the type designer.

With regards to the Germanization of Gill Sans, that would appear to be another special case. Perhaps this pandered to the stereotype of European modernism. Or perhaps, soon after WWII (which is when I believe it was manufactured, not before), there was a feeling that Gill Sans was too ﬁrmly associated with England, and this would have negative connotations in Germany.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414004031im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GillGerman_4324.jpg)

From an undated Monotype specimen (probably early 1950s), Belserdruck, Stuttgart.  
"M 10, Serie 262-11, Durchschuß 2"  
There is also Bold, but no Light shown.

Yeah, I don’t think there’s a connection there. It’s nice that you’re putting a single-story g as an alternate, but I’d see no reason to make it a locl.

Samples like that Gill, I would see that rather in a historical than a geographic context (“pandered to the stereotype of European modernism” sounds right; weren’t there lots of faces that suddenly came up with Futura-esque alternates…).  
Durchschuß means leading, FWIW.
Yes, the “Germanization” of Gill Sans can rather be regarded as “Futura-ization”. There will be an article of this “German Gill Sans” on Fonts In Use later this year.
